title: Édouard Manet

thumbnail.alt_text: Portrait of a straight-faced, light-skinned man with a bushy, light-brown beard and rosy cheeks wearing a dark vest, jacket, and shiny top hat. He grasps a thin cane, held horizontally, with both hands.

description: Finely dressed and carrying an elegant walking stick, influential French artist Édouard Manet appears before a stark background evocative of his own paintings as well as photographic portraits of the time. Created by his friend Henri Fantin-Latour, this depiction confronted the public perception of Manet as a radical bohemian painter of coarse and confrontational compositions (for an example of this, see his Jesus Mocked by the Soldiers). Fantin-Latour instead portrayed him as the genteel man-about-town he actually was.
inscriptions: Inscribed lower left: A mon Ami Manet. / Fantin. 1867.

provenance_text: Inherited by Edouard Manet’s wife, Suzanne Manet, Paris to at least 1889 [lent to Paris, 1889]; possibly Camentron, Paris [acc. to Paris 1983].  Gustave Tempelaere with Allard and Noel, Paris, by 1900; sold to Durand-Ruel, Paris, 1900 [Durand-Ruel photo no. 938, stock no. 5666]; sold to the Art Institute, 1905.
